title: Fort Worth police chief: 'absolutely no excuse' for officer killing black woman
text:
The interim Fort Worth police chief said on Tuesday there was “absolutely no excuse” for a white officer’s fatal shooting of a black woman inside her home.

Police say Atatiana Jefferson, 28, was killed by shot fired through a window early on Saturday morning, as officers responded to a report of an open door. Jefferson had been playing video games with her eight-year-old nephew.

At a press conference, Ed Kraus grew emotional when describing the morale of the police department.

“Officers are hurting,” he said. Kraus said he had not encountered an officer who disagreed with the decision to arrest Aaron Dean, and pleaded with Fort Worth residents to not let the conduct of one officer reflect on the whole department.

At least five people have been shot dead by Fort Worth police officers this year.

Kraus said Dean did not make a statement to investigators before resigning on Monday. Kraus said he would have been fired if he had not quit voluntarily.

Dean was arrested on Monday night on a murder charge in the shooting death of Atatiana Jefferson. He is out of custody after posting bond, which was set at $200,000.

Jefferson was devoted to her family and had moved into her mother’s Fort Worth home earlier this year to help as her mom’s health declined, relatives said. With her mother in the hospital, Jefferson and her eight-year-old nephew were the only two people home when she was shot.

The 28-year-old, who family members sometimes called “Tay”, had the front door of the home open to let the cool breeze in, said Lee Merritt, an attorney for the family.

“They did that all night from sunset until the time that they lost track of time … when they heard someone prowling around in the bushes,” Merritt said during a news conference with the family on Monday.

“He and his Auntie Tay experienced the fear of someone prowling in the backyard,” Merritt said. “His Auntie Tay did not allow him to check the window, she checked herself.”

Officer Dean fired a split second after shouting at Jefferson to show her hands. Police bodycam video shows the officer did not identify himself as police.

Amber Carr said her sister loved spending time with her nephews.

“My sister, the relationship she has with my sons is indescribable. Sometimes people think that they are her kids and not mine,” said Carr, who also has a four-year-old son.

She said the last time she spoke to her sister was a week before she was killed.

“She came to the hospital in Plano where I was recovering from a major heart surgery. She came and brought me food, she brought me a new cellphone,” Carr said.

Jefferson loved playing basketball and video games with the eight-year-old and also “helped him become more independent and self-sufficient”, Carr said.

When Carr picked the eight-year-old up at a facility where police took him after Jefferson was killed, it was the boy who told his mother about the shooting.
